intro: Camelina lasiocarpa, commonly known as the rough-hairy camelina, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. It typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Camelina lasiocarpa is also valued for its potential as a source of oilseed and for its ecological benefits in supporting pollinators.
